awd_abstract_narration:
The rich record of stories, vocabularies, and analyses of Indigenous languages found in archival manuscript collections are critical language infrastructure to advance linguists’ understanding of these languages and Indigenous communities’ goals of cultivating new generations of speakers of Native languages. Yet even when archives digitize these manuscripts, they face new challenges as they look to make the information within these under-utilized documents easier to examine and use in a digital setting for multiple audiences. The Indigenous Language Manuscript Interface (ILMI) project will contribute new solutions to this widespread issue in linguistics and archiving through a collaboration between the oldest language archive in the United States, the American Philosophical Society (APS), and the Language and Cultural Revitalization Program of the Tunica-Biloxi Tribe of Louisiana (TBT). The ILMI project will create a new open-source platform that can be hosted by archives themselves, allowing researchers to navigate and view digitized original pages of manuscripts in endangered languages alongside data of the original text and data added by linguists and community language experts. 

To develop a pilot example of this platform, this project focuses on the 1930s Tunica language notebooks of the influential linguist Mary Haas and the last fluent Tunica speaker, Sesostrie Youchigant. These notebooks constitute the largest set of Tunica language documentation ever created. The TBT’s language experts and apprentices will produce transcriptions, transliterations, and additional information, integrating community expertise into the project and providing opportunities for language apprentices to expand their training. A TEI-encoded initial version of the interface will be produced by the end of Year 1. In Year 2, the lead linguist will create thorough analyses, annotations, and multimedia resource enhancements in collaboration with the TBT, leading to a finished Tunica language portal hosted by the APS. APS archivists will demonstrate the broader application of this new framework to digitized presentations of thousands of pages manuscripts in dozens of other Native languages, creating linked content guides to help all audiences explore these resources. The APS will provide the Tunica data produced by the project as open data sets available to researchers. It will also promote the ILMI framework for broader adoption by other language archives, and by linguists seeking to enhance the usability of archival manuscripts with their own contributions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The American Philosophical Society’s (APS) Library & Museum, through its Center for Native American and Indigenous Research (CNAIR) was honored to partner with the Tunica-Biloxi Tribe of Louisiana and its Language and Cultural Revitalization Program (LCRP) and the linguist Patricia Anderson on this project. The center of this project is a set of 14 notebooks containing over 2,000 handwritten pages of Tunica stories, language information, and cultural knowledge recorded by the linguist Mary R. Haas in the 1930s with Sesostrie Youchigant, the last known fluent speaker of Tunica. These notebooks, which are housed at the APS Library and now fully digitized and accessible in its Digital Library, were extensively transcribed, transliterated into the contemporary Tunica writing system, given in-depth linguistic analysis, and provided with commentaries and context by members of the Tunica-Biloxi Tribe through video interviews


The materials were transcribed, primarily by tribal members who are Tunica language teachers and learners, into a Fieldworks Language Explorer (FLEx) database that was begun and is used by the Tunica-Biloxi LCRP and the Kohpani Yoyani Luchi Yoroni (KYLY) or Tunica Language Working Group, in collaboration with CNAIR. This current state of the database is now downloadable as the richest set of analyzed Tunica data available, which can be used by researchers to further the linguistic study of this language. 


This use of the Tunica transcription also served as a pilot project for developing an Indigenous Languages Manuscript Interface (ILMI) which can then be applied to other Indigenous language manuscript materials with transcriptions and/or tables of contents to enhance the navigability and usability of those materials. Due to significant technological changes over the course of the project, the original means of displaying the transcriptions alongside the digitized original was not successfully realized, though promising new methodologies are now in active development. There was great success in developing a key aspect of the interface for integrating linked Tables of Contents into the presentation of the Tunica manuscripts and nearly 10,000 digitized pages of original fieldwork manuscripts on over a dozen other Indigenous languages of North America. This tool greatly increases transparency about the contents of these predominantly unpublished materials and makes it possible to navigate them with ease. In this way the materials are not just accessible, but far more usable.  


The project also created a website portal introducing and contextualizing these Tunica resources at the APS with the inclusion of video and textual commentaries by Tunica community members multiple generations. This resource provides context and perspective in the words of Tunica people themselves for scholarly and general public audiences interested in exploring the notebooks. 


This new, unprecedented availability of the content of these notebooks makes this overall body of work a robust resource for not only linguistics, but other fields such as historical studies, ethnobotany, ethnomusicology, and anthropology, as well as to the broader public interested in these topics and, especially, to the Tunica-Biloxi community itself. The notebooks contain numerous sections of detailed discussion in both Tunica and English on all of these topics, now far more easily apparent and discoverable through linked Tables of Contents, keyword searchability, access to digital originals, and commentary from contemporary Tunica community members in their own words.


Last Modified: 05/24/2024
Modified by: Brian L Carpenter
